resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: JDBC driver on rs.getFloat() gives LossOfPrecisionConversionException for float fields containing Float.MAX_VALUE

creator.name: miteshm
creator.emailAddress: mitesh dot meswani at sun dot com

reporter.name: miteshm
reporter.emailAddress: mitesh dot meswani at sun dot com

author.name: hmork
author.emailAddress: havard dot mork at gmail dot com

comments.body: Attached suggested patch for the problem. The problem occurs by a inaccuracy when casting float.max_value to double for comparison. IJ avoids the problem by using getDouble instead.

updateAuthor.name: hmork
updateAuthor.emailAddress: havard dot mork at gmail dot com

author.name: miteshm
author.emailAddress: mitesh dot meswani at sun dot com

comments.body:
Thanks for looking into this. I don't have environment setup to build Derby. I will not be able to try the patch. Does the test case in the bug run successfully with the patch? 

>IJ avoids the problem by using getDouble instead.
This is not an option for us as we are implenenting Java Persistence API in Glassfish and the code that reads value from the result set is generic and common to all databases. 

Do you have expected date this would get checked in?

Thanks,
Mitesh

updateAuthor.name: miteshm
updateAuthor.emailAddress: mitesh dot meswani at sun dot com

author.name: bryanpendleton
author.emailAddress: bpendleton dot derby at gmail dot com

comments.body:
Attached is a patch containing a regression test for this bug:
derby-1136-reg-test.diff. If anyone has time to look at this
patch, I would be very grateful.

I intend to commit the regression test, unless somebody feels
like that would be a bad idea.

I found myself interested in this bug, for reasons I can't
totally explain. Floating point is still rather a mystery to
me, and so I enjoy fooling around with it when I get a chance.

In particular, the notion that there was a floating point value
which was greater than Float.MAX_VALUE, but which when cast to
float returns FALSE from Float.isInfinite(), intrigued me, so
I wrote a little program (test.java) to explore that behavior
and am attaching it for anyone who wants to share my joy in
floating point behaviors...

While developing the regression test, I discovered two things:
1) The JCC 2.4 driver also suffers from this bug. If anybody has
a way to pass this fix along to the JCC team, they might be
grateful.
2) I don't really understand why the patch to this problem also
includes a change to SQLDouble.java. From what I can tell, that
change is not necessary to resolve the behavior reported by this
bug; only the change to CrossConverters.java is needed. Still,
the change to SQLDouble seems reasonable to me, and I'm not
opposed to it. I just didn't write a regression test for it,
because I don't understand it. :)

updateAuthor.name: bryanpendleton
updateAuthor.emailAddress: bpendleton dot derby at gmail dot com

author.name: hmork
author.emailAddress: havard dot mork at gmail dot com

comments.body: I changed SQLDouble.java in order to address the same behaviour in the embedded driver also. I'm a newbie here, so I'm unsure wether that constitute a problem. Is it necessary to check for net client in the regression test?

updateAuthor.name: hmork
updateAuthor.emailAddress: havard dot mork at gmail dot com

author.name: bryanpendleton
author.emailAddress: bpendleton dot derby at gmail dot com

comments.body:
Thank you for the information about the SQLDouble change.

Your comment helped me realize that derbynet/prepStmt.java is not the best location for the regression test, because those tests run only for the network server environments, not for the embedded environment.

Therefore, I've attached a new patch, 'derby-1136-resultset-reg-test.diff', which moves the regression test to jdbcapi/resultset.java. The resultset regression test runs in the embedded environment as well as in the network server environment.

With this new test, I am able to confirm *both* of your fixes. That is, when I backed both your fixes out of my sandbox, resultset.java produces the expected exception failure in both the embedded and DerbyNetClient configurations. Then, when I restored the SQLDouble.java change, the embedded test works. And when I restored the CrossConverters.java change, the DerbyNetClient test works. This makes me much happier about the regression test, since now it confirms both fixes.

Please let me know of any other comments about this patch.

updateAuthor.name: bryanpendleton
updateAuthor.emailAddress: bpendleton dot derby at gmail dot com

author.name: bryanpendleton
author.emailAddress: bpendleton dot derby at gmail dot com

comments.body:
I've committed the regression test to subversion:
http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=389575&view=rev

updateAuthor.name: bryanpendleton
updateAuthor.emailAddress: bpendleton dot derby at gmail dot com

comments.body:
Committed revision 407519 to 10.1 branch
NOTE: Regression test (Rev. 389575) not (yet?) merged.

Should this issue be closed?

The regression test cannot be merged into 10.1 without conflict on all files. This fix is very small, and have a regression test on trunk, so I suggest we don't backport the test to 10.1, but close this issue. Unless there are someone that has the itch to backport the test, of course.

author.name: fuzzylogic

comments.body: This issue has been resolved for over a year with no further movement. Closing.
